name: Jess
review:
I'm olive complected with dry skin and this is the best palette ever. I've already gone though my Metropolitan palette and am thinking of buying the Impressionist because I love a natural look.

The accent, glittery part is a tiny bit messy but is a nice touch to the eyes overall.

Wonderful product for a great price!

name: esa
review: Love that it's not hard to take off and the colors are amazing

name: lorin
review: goes on very easily, great color, dont have to put a ton on to get color, can glam it up or wear it toned down!

name: StellaBlue002
review: I've never mastered the art of blending eyeshadow and my 'smoky eyes' always leave me looking like a racoon. This eyeshadow palette is for dummies like me. It's foolproof. The colors are gorgeous and I love the touch of shimmer. It's perfect for a casual or daytime look.

name: Jillbles
review:
I recently found out that I'm allergic to... um, everything. Seriously, if it's got lanolin, cocamidapropyl betaine, propylene glycol, methylisothiazolinone, or a number of other ingredients, I can't wear it. I lost hundreds of dollars in personal care products because most of them contained propylene glycol. Bare Minerals powders are, so far, safe. And so is this palette from Revlon, and their long-lasting lip stain/gloss.
I now have Pop Art and Renaissance palettes from this line. I love Pop Art; it's surprisingly versatile for a green palette. You don't HAVE to use the super sparkly glitter accent, if you don't want to, which is nice; I'm not exactly a party girl, and there's plenty of sparkle in the regular palette without going full-on SPARKLY.
Renaissance surprised me, as the main color is a much darker gray than I was expecting. Pretty, and it ended up working for my needs on that particular day, in the end. But be aware, this is less subtle gray, more CHECK ME OUT I'M GOTH.
There is a lot of fallout during application on both palettes, but once applied, it stayed on nicely. I didn't notice much in the way of creasing. The first times I used it, I went without primer (Urban Decay, which is what I had and loved, has propylene glycol); I did OK. For Renaissance, I had acquired a Bare Essentials eyelid primer without PG; worked out very nicely, but I probably could've gotten by without it.

name: care
review: I like the neutral colors, I don't apply it exactly as shown on the case, I like to the put the lighter shade on the top lid by my lashes to make a more youthful look with brighter eyes. I'm fair with freckles and red hair, but I think these colors will look good on almost everyone.

name: Food Hussy
review: I like this one - it has quite a few options for combinations. I also like that it came with two applicators - so you can have a separate side for each color. The glitter in it is a good balance too - it's not too young or over the top.

review: This is a great product for someone that doesn't know how to apply different shades of eye shadow.  It's a no brainer.

review: Doesn't crease....oh man, I hate shadows that crease after 4 hours...not this one, put on the primer, then the shadow. ALL DAY STAY!

review: Love this shadow palette.  Wonderful colors with deep pigmentation.  Love love

name: kc41005
review: I own this in Impressionist and Metropolitan. I  purchased these when I was in the denial stage about how great the Naked palettes could possibly be so I purchased these instead, liking the shades offered. Here's my opinion- The shades that are meant to be primers are definitely lacking sufficient priming potential. They in no way compare to a liquid primer, so I took them for just another color in the palette and used my normal primer with them. Even with a good primer the color tends to fade fast. The glitter colors barely show up at all and they flake so bad it just turns your face into a hot mess, so that eliminated the want to use those. I do like the smoky greige in the Impressionist set, however as a whole this was the final straw that caused me to cave and buy the Naked 1 palette. Other shadows just don't compare in my opinion.

name: loverUNDfighter
review: I received this compact from Santa and can't stop playing with it. It is comprised of three purples and two sea-foam/green shades for accent. Although I have the #540 compact which is named "muse" and isn't pictured on the site you can google it and see what I'm raving about. I appreciate the numbered and color coded picture on the back for easy application and the shadows blend seamlessly. My only issue is the slight creasing in my lid but this is due to my lids and not the product.

review: I really love these colors because they are neutral and blends beautifully on my dark skin tone.

name: LadyBorgia
review: I don't purchase Revlon often, but I saw this in 'Avant Garde' and ADORED the colors. A red flag should have gone off when I saw the sponge applicators from 1985 (even mini sample products come with a little brush or expect you to have a little purse sized set...or even one....I do as do most peoplr.) Anyway, the primer was ridiculous  (just light colored eyeshadow (depending on the look) that we all lay down after our actual concealer or eye primer) and I knew I was in trouble when I swatched it after opening  (HUGE problem of drugstore cosmetics! You can't swatch before buying so good stuff gets passed up unless you get a trusted source to vouch for it!) Pigments looked nothing like in the pans, except possibly the dark crease color, which was close, but muddier. I gave it a go anyway and the color payout is terrible and after packing a ridiculous amount of  the lid color on I *finally* got somewhat near the lid pan color, but patchy and blotchy no matter what I did (brush, finger...even terrible little sponges.) I'm skilled at make up application, but followed the directions as if a beginner (as this palette is set up for that.) Sorry Revlon, but this blends horribly, pigments are horrid and really is a rip off unless you just want to look at it in the package. Then it's very pretty. I thought maybe it might work as a facial highlighter.....mehhh nope! Save your money!!!!

review: I love this particular Revlon Product.  The color is pigmented to last.  It also has a primer and a small sparkle section for fun.   My favorite colors are the light blue and the nudes.

name: Joey
review:
I have this in Impressionist. Overall the palette leans towards okay, but is mostly meh. The colors you can see are great, however, only two of the colors have any real color payoff. The eye-shaped pan (a nice medium brown) and the one above it (a nice dark brown). I bought this palette because of the included "primer" (the large rectangular shade). However, was disappointed to find it did nothing for the other shadows, I have treated it like an extra shadow and find it to be minimally pigmented. With real primer under these it took a while to build up any color from this particular shadow. The lightest shade (top pan) took more time for still almost no color to show up. The glitter (square pan) was the same, but created a huge mess. The closeness of all the pans and craziness of the glitter made the palette itself a mess. It is sad to say that my ELF and wet 'n wild palettes have a higher quality for less.

Pros:
5 shadows
2 pigmented shadows

Cons:
3/5 shadows are basically useless
Primer does nothing
Poor quality, especially for price
